Yes, while the Dartford LEZ has generally been seen as a positive move to improve air quality, there have been some criticisms of the policy and challenges in enforcing it.

One criticism is that the LEZ only covers a small area, so it may not have a significant impact on overall air pollution levels in the Dartford area. Additionally, some have argued that the daily charge to enter the zone may disproportionately affect lower-income families and businesses with older, less fuel-efficient vehicles.

Another criticism is that the LEZ relies on automatic number plate recognition (ANPR) cameras to enforce the policy, which can be unreliable and may lead to errors in charging. Some drivers have reported receiving charges even though their vehicles meet the required emissions standards.

Furthermore, some have noted that the LEZ policy may not go far enough in addressing air pollution, and that more stringent measures, such as a larger coverage area or stricter emissions standards, may be necessary to make a meaningful impact.

Despite these criticisms and challenges, the Dartford LEZ has generally been seen as a positive step towards improving air quality in the area, and its effectiveness is supported by the reduction in nitrogen dioxide and particulate matter levels recorded since its introduction.
